Award.AwardTitle: Single Cell Visualization of DNA Repair Using Digital Fluorescent Holography
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, in order to understand the process of the repair of broken chromosomes the PI will visualize their motion in vivo. The physical properties of chromosomes such as the end-to-end distance, collision rate and the cyclization rate will be measured for comparison to the prediction of theoretical models of biopolymers. The affects of the physical constraints such as the chromosomal tethering to the nuclear periphery as well as the variation in homology length will be addressed systematically. A novel fluorescent holographic microscope will be used to improve current methods of three-dimensional microscopy and to visualize the dynamics of these biopolymers. The experiments will be performed in a microfluidic device where a precise control over the microenvironment of cells is possible. Using a microfluidic progeny chamber in combination with precise image analysis, the PI will investigate the repair process at the single cell level and characterize the cell-to-cell variability of the repair process.

The PI has modified an existing lecture course for freshman in biophysics to include experiments in modern quantitative biology. The PI has also started a collaborative effort among the Departments of Physics, Biology and the Education Program at Brandeis University to launch a summer workshop for high school teachers in the subject of modern methods of microscopy applied to quantitative biology. The workshop will familiarize high school teachers with cutting edge techniques in quantitative biology and give them ideas for new experiments in their classrooms. The participants will take home all the materials that they had used during the workshop, including the inexpensive student-grade fluorescent microscope that the PI has co-developed at Brandeis University and the pre-made fluorescent slides for use in their schools science program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of our research can be summarized in the following four statements:

 1) To visualize the real-time dynamics of the DNA double-strand break and repair during the mating type switching of model organism Yeast.

2) To construct novel devices for observation of DNA repair at single cell level.

3) To characterize the cell-to-cell variability of the DNA repair.

4) To construct a physical model of the chromosomal arrangements within the nucleus in general and to predict the dynamics of the DNA repair in particular.

During the first and second years of the funding, we successfully built several strains to quantitatively visualize DNA break and repair process. We quantitatively measured the static properties of the chromosomes such as the end-to-end distances and the angle between the two telomeres. We also deleted genes responsible for tethering the telomeres to the nuclear envelope. Release of this confinement significantly changed the distribution of end-end distances. During the second year of funding, we developed a physical model for the chromosome architecture in the yeast nucleus. The “Geometric model” is based three crucial observations: 1) all centromeres are attached to a structure at the nuclear periphery named spindle pole body 2) all the telomeres are randomly distributed around the nuclear periphery and 3) the distances between the SPB-telomere is a function of the chromosomal arm.  Using these observations the end-end distance of all related and unrelated chromosomes can be calculated and compared to the experiments. The Geometric model successfully predicts -with no fitting parameter- the distribution of end-end distances for all yeast chromosomes. This prediction was compared to our own as well as others’ data. The Geometric model also successfully predicts the end-end distances, when the tethering proteins were deleted.  

We have developed several microfluidic devices for single cell observation of the yeast cells. The first device was originally designed by Dr. Amy Rowat (Department of Integrative Biology and Physiology, UCLA). During our collaboration, we developed and tested several microfluidic devices to follow a single cell and its progeny during the DNA repair. Using the “progeny” device and other single cell observation chambers, we successfully measured the duration of the DNA repair in single cells and their progeny in a population of genetically identical cells. This was done by fluorescently tagging a protein that accumulates at the site of the break, and falls off soon after the completion of the repair.

We discovered that the duration of the repair varies greatly from cell-to-cell even in the population of genetically identical cells. With some cells repairing their DNA within 30 minutes while others would take 2.5 hours to complete the process.  We also discovered that there is a high correlation between the duration of the repair, and the duration of the arrest before the mitosis. We did not however find any significant correlation in repair times, between the mother and daughter cells.   

Having a Biophysics lab in the physics department, presents a great research opportunity to undergraduate and graduate Physics students. In my lab, students are exposed to a new field of physics and learn many new techniques that are not taught in a traditional physics curriculum.

During the past five years, I have worked with 12 undergraduate students, one graduate student and two post doctoral associates. All undergraduate students were involved in every aspect of the project including data collection using fluorescence microscopy, data analysis, writing image processing code in Matlab and writing manuscripts. They all learned how to use Matlab to write very sophisticated image processing code.
